newsitem.title: USA: Merger to reunite Red Adair firefighting veterans.
newsitem.headline: Merger to reunite Red Adair firefighting veterans.

text.p: Two rival Houston-based international oil well firefighting firms Tuesday announced plans to merge by late July in a deal that reunites veterans of the legendary Red Adair's former company.
In the deal, International Well Control will acquire the assets of Boots & Coots LP to form a new company, Boots & Coots/IWC. Financial terms were not disclosed.

The Houston-based company will be headed by Brian Krause, who formed International Well Control in 1994 along with a group of senior firefighters after Adair retired and sold his business to Global Industries Ltd. in late 1993.
Asger "Boots" Hansen and Edward Owen "Coots" Matthews, who left Adair's company to form Boots & Coots in 1978, will be consultants to the new company.

Adair began his career with well firefighting pioneer Myron Kinley, and found fame on the cover of Life magazine after extinguishing the "Devil's cigarette lighter," a massive Middle East oil well fire in the late 1950s.
His legendary status grew with the 1968 release of the John Wayne movie "Hellfighters," a film based loosely on Adair's career which glamorized the gritty life of the international well firefighter.
Crews from the two companies extinguished 245 of the 700 well fires set by Iraqi troops as they retreated from Kuwait at the end of the Gulf War.
In the past month, the companies joined forces to battle a well explosion and fire that killed four rig workers in Louisiana, and separate blowouts in West Texas and Bangladesh.

"We've started to see quite an increase in the last year here," said Krause, who said stepped-up drilling and ageing wells were contributing to more frequent blowouts. "You also don't have the experienced personnel that you used to have."
The deal continues a steady consolidation in the well firefighting industry, which has shrunk to three active companies from 10 since the 1991 Gulf War.
The acquisition is expected to close by July 31, and Boots & Coots/IWC is considering a public stock offering to expand its international operations, Krause said.
The company will continue IWC's WellCall venture with Halliburton Energy Services, and plans to expand operations to battle tanker and refinery fires, he said.
